comments.body:
Not a comment on this PR, but why is this in JS - couldn't it just be a normal HTML link.

(JS that could be written as plain HTML is a bug bear of mine)

> (JS that could be written as plain HTML is a bug bear of mine)

True.

I think this could work.
```html
<form action="/dagmodel/edit/{{ dag.dag_id }}">
  <button id="btn_edit_dagrun" type="submit" class="btn btn-primary">
              Edit
  </button>
</form>
```
instead of this
```html
<button id="btn_edit_dagrun" type="button" class="btn btn-primary">
            Edit
</button>
```
@feng-tao @XD-DENG @verdan What do you guys think? Should we change the links generated in JS to HTML links where possible?

that would be awesome!! I was also working on a PR to extract all inline JS from .html files to separate .js files. 
I was using `data-url` attribute to move all the URLs inside html and use this attribute to access the url in .js files. 
P.S: I'll continue working on that in coming weeks, as was busy removing the old UI before.

The advantage of using `url_for('DagModelView.show', pk=dag.dag_id)` is that we don't have to worry about the url generation and if flask, for some reason, changes this url from `/show/<pk>` to `/show?<pk>` we do not need to change anything.
@verdan Do you think we can disregard this?
@ashb As @verdan says he is working on this change. So should we get that into `master` so he can rebase onto it and change this as well?

You should avoid Jinja in Javascript. I will correct it in my PR.
Reference: 
https://github.com/apache/airflow/pull/4787

diffHunk:

                  "&dag_id=" + encodeURIComponent(dag_id) +
